Award.AwardTitle: Interaction between electrical activity and bone morphogenetic proteins: Consequences to spinal cord differentiation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Connections among neurons and with target cells enable the plethora of nervous system tasks. The establishment of these connections relies on the specialization of neurons during development, which in the spinal cord is regulated by a family of proteins known as bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs). The current view is that these proteins trigger a genetically hardwired program that establishes the fate of cells along the dorsoventral axis of the developing spinal cord. However, differentiation of embryonic neurons is also sensitive to electrical activity, which manifests spontaneously in these developing cells. This study will test the hypothesis that a gradient of BMPs across the dorsoventral axis of the nervous system contributes to establish a gradient of calcium-dependent electrical activity in immature spinal neurons that, in turn, regulates neuronal differentiation. A multi-approach study using molecular, pharmacological, biochemical and physiological techniques will be implemented. This investigation may lead to new ways of thinking on how the nervous system develops and will challenge the idea that nervous system development is exclusively genetically driven. Results from this project may identify novel mechanisms of action of BMPs of relevance to many research fields, including developmental biology, neuroscience, stem cells and tissue repair. Overall, this study will contribute to the understanding of how to induce restorative plastic events in a pathological context of loss or impaired nervous system function.

The PI will serve as role model for female and latino students and colleagues. This award will support both graduate and undergraduate students, and the PI will institute a multistep research experience for the Sacramento High School District in the context of outreach activities coordinated by the Center for Biophotonics. The PI will also continue to support international Neuroscience research in developing countries such as Argentina, through participation in argentine scientific meetings and training courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The discoveries that have resulted from this study contribute to a shift in paradigm with regard to the understanding of neuronal differentiation and morphogenetic protein action during nervous system development. We found that the bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) regulate calcium-mediated electrical activity present in developing spinal neurons. In turn, this activity modifies BMP action and its regulation of spinal neuron specification (Figure 1). The novelty of these findings resides at several levels. First, we identify novel signaling pathways linking morphogenetic proteins with calcium signaling. Second, we show that the differentiation of spinal neurons into dorsal and ventral phenotypes is not only dependent on the gradient of morphogenetic proteins but also on the level of calcium spike activity. Third, we demonstrate that morphogenetic proteins such as BMPs do not only target progenitor cells for the specification of different neuronal identities in the developing spinal cord. Instead, they regulate neuronal differentiation even in the already “fated” postmitotic neuron.

The findings from this project have made a significant impact in the field of Developmental Neuroscience and Developmental Biology. The accepted paradigm for the specialization of different neuronal phenotypes argues for a genetically hardwired program that starts in the early stages of nervous system formation and through which cells are fated to a specific phenotype even before they are actually born, which means from the specification of the neural progenitor from which the neuron is originated. In contrast, we find that manipulating calcium-mediated activity and its interaction with BMPs modifies the differentiation of spinal neurons. Hence, our research challenges the rigid concept of cell fate, which assumes that cells are predetermined to become a specific phenotype. Instead our findings propose that integrating environmental, intracellular and extracellular cues is part of the journey that an immature neuron undergoes before adopting a certain feature and ultimately a specific phenotype.

Together with our findings on the interaction between calcium spike activity in spinal neurons and the morphogenetic protein Sonic hedgehog (Shh), which is present in an opposite gradient to BMPs in the developing spinal cord, we propose a model by which these major developmental cues modulate the level of electrical activity along the embryonic spinal cord and reciprocally, their signaling and action are regulated by calcium-mediated activity (Figure 2). This dynamic interplay enables a rather plastic process of neuronal differentiation that can integrate intrinsic and extrinsic signals to develop the best-equipped neural circuit.

Nineteen publications and twenty-five presentations in scientific meetings have been produced during the period of this award.    

 

Broader Impacts

The awarded project has allowed me to train, mentor and support two postdoctoral fellows (Swapna Immani and Yesser Hadj Belgacem), two graduate students (Kira Spencer and Jacqueline Levin), six undergraduate students (Jesse Dingle, Veronica Hernandez, Harsh Sharma, Abraham De la Cruz, Daniel Williams, Frances Keller), three high school students (Pratyush Joshi, Aishwarya Pattnaik, Henry Genus), one MD graduate from Uruguay (Pablo Joaquin Erramouspe), and a research associate (Olesya Visina).

Veronica Hernandez and Jesse Dingle were undergraduate students at the community colleges Contra Costa and Yuba, respectively, and joined the lab for summer internships as participants of the Center for Biophotonics and Fastrac Internship Program in which the PI contributed as a mentor. Veronica Hernandez participated in this program during two summers. Both, Veronica and Jesse were selected and sponsored to present their research progress at the Society for Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) Annual Meetings.

Harsh Sharma, a former UC Davis undergraduate presented his research progress at the Undergraduate Research & Creative Activities Conference, UC Davis.

I contributed to the Brain Awareness Week by participating in the Davis Farmers Market booth to outreach to the general community about advances in neuroscience and the research done at UC Davis. 

I have participated as a mentor in the Society for Neuroscience Mentorship Program by mentoring two Latino graduate students: Dana Levine and Yakeel Quiroz.

I have supervised three undergraduate students, Abraham De la Cruz, Daniel Williams and Frances Keller, from BYU Idaho, four additional graduate students, Michelle Tu, who graduated in the fall of 2013, Olga Balashova, who graduated in the summer of 2015 and Albert Lee and Raman Goyal who joined the lab in December 2014; two project scientists, Yesser Hadj Belgacem (2012-06/2016) and Sangwoo Shim (04/2014-present); and five postdoctoral fellows, Eduardo Bouth Sequerra (2009-2013), Patricio Castro (2012-2014), Olga Balashova (07/2015-present) and Andrew Hamilton (11/2013-present), Eva Grossinger (2017-Present).

I have served as a judge in a Science Fair in a Sacramento School district high school, West Campus and have demonstrated to elementary school children from Shalom School, Sacramento, on the frog life cycle and cell division. We are currently developing a K-to-12 program for the children patients at the Shriners Hospital for Children Northern California.
